bioghist.p: Hope Emily Allen (1883-1960), noteworthy medieval scholar, is best known for her research on the 14th century English mystic Richard Rolle and for her discovery of the Book of Margery Kempe. Allen received her bachelor's and master's degrees from Bryn Mawr College. She later did graduate work at Radcliffe and Cambridge. Allen described herself as an "independent scholar," and she never accepted an academic teaching appointment. Her writing falls into three overlapping groups: her early work on the Ancrene Riwle, her insight into the study of Richard Rolle, and her research on the cultural background of the Book of Margery Kempe.

scopecontent.p: The papers consist primarily of research notes by Allen, typescripts of medieval manuscripts (some in translation), photostats of printed medieval texts, and professional correspondence. Topics include the Book of Margery Kempe, Julian of Norwich, the Ancrene Riwle,and Richard Rolle. The collection also includes a set of scrapbooks of clippings about the discovery of the Book of Margery Kempe.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
